text: We'll hear argument now on number oh one five twenty-one, The Republican Party of Minnesota, et al., versus Verna Kelly.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court: Like most states Minnesota selects its judges through periodic popular elections.
Could we find out from you just what the Announce Clause prohibits that isn't already prohibited by the Pledges and Promises Clause, as it's been interpreted?
How does that differ, then, from the Pledges or Promises Clause?
The Predges [: Pledges] and Promises Clause prohibits any pledge or promise that other than faithful performance of duties in office.
But you think the Announce Clause, even as interpreted by the Eighth Circuit to be the same as the ABA canon, goes beyond that?
Well, Your Honor, there is one aspect of the current nineteen ninety ABA can- n- canon that has was not discussed by the Ninth Circuit or by the ABA brief.
does that appear in your brief? Where where is the ABA canon we're talking about? Where is it? I want to look at it while you're talking about it.
I do not have a reference to the ABA canon, Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it may it please the Court: I would like to take the opportunity to try to clarify some of the questions and answers that have been provided as...
Your Honor, I don't think this's a matter of mathematical precision.
